abstract.p: Play of New York Islanders rookie Taylor Pyatt in training camp discussed (S)

block.p: He may not have earned a spot on the Islanders' roster -- yet. But the rookie Taylor Pyatt has earned himself a long, hard look.
With a week remaining until the start of the regular season, Pyatt, 19, is the lone skater with no N.H.L. experience still left in the Islanders' training camp.
He may not have earned a spot on the Islanders' roster -- yet. But the rookie Taylor Pyatt has earned himself a long, hard look.
With a week remaining until the start of the regular season, Pyatt, 19, is the lone skater with no N.H.L. experience still left in the Islanders' training camp.
The top prospects Branislav Mezei and Juraj Kolnick are long gone.

Goaltender Rick DiPietro has been sent to the Chicago Wolves of the International Hockey League. On Tuesday, Raffi Torres, a left wing, was sent back to juniors, where he will play with the Brampton Battalion of the Ontario Hockey League.
And Pyatt, the son of the former N.H.L. player Nelson Pyatt, is still here.

''He's earned himself the opportunity to get a longer look,'' Coach Butch Goring said of Taylor Pyatt, the Islanders' second pick in the first round of the 1999 entry draft. ''Lucky for him he's a left-hander. This is his big chance to see if he's earned it. We're not looking for 19-year-olds to carry this team.''
But the Islanders are looking closely at Pyatt. At 6 feet 4 inches, 220 pounds, Pyatt is built along the lines of a power forward, although he is not known for being a tremendously physical player.
He is, however, a tremendous skater who can move like a a much smaller player.
